content.text: A ratio is an ordered comparison of quantities of the same kind. A rate is an ordered comparison of quantities of different kinds. One of the most common rates we use is speed, which is a comparison between the distance travelled and the time taken.
Speed is a comparison between distance travelled and time taken. The slope of a graph gives the rate of change of one variable with respect to the other.

Common examples of rates include: Rates of pay (dollars per hour or euros per hour), Petrol consumption (litres per 100 km or km per litre), Annual rainfall (mm per year), Unit cost (dollars per kilogram or pounds per kg), Population density (people per square kilometre).

content.label: Example 1
content.question: A tap fills a 9 litre bucket in 3 minutes. Express this as a rate in simplest form.
solution: \text{rate} = \frac{9 \text{ L}}{3 \text{ minutes}}
\therefore \text{rate} = \frac{9}{3} \text{ L per minute}
\therefore \text{rate} = 3 \text{ L per minute}

content.text: To properly compare prices we need to convert the cost of an item into a rate called a unit cost. This could be the cost per gram, the cost per kilogram, the cost per litre or similar. We then compare the unit costs for packages of different sizes.

content.label: Example 2
content.question: Which box of Sudso detergent gives better value for money? A: 500 g costing $3.50 or B: 750 g costing $5.40
solution: \textbf{A: } \text{unit cost} = \frac{350 \text{ cents}}{500 \text{ grams}} = 0.7 \text{ cents per gram}
\textbf{B: } \text{unit cost} = \frac{540 \text{ cents}}{750 \text{ grams}} = 0.72 \text{ cents per gram}
\text{So, A is better value.}

content.label: Example 3
content.question: Henry eats peanuts at a constant rate of 24 every 3 minutes. How many peanuts will he eat in 10 minutes?
solution: \text{Henry's rate of eating peanuts} = \frac{24 \text{ peanuts}}{3 \text{ minutes}} = 8 \text{ peanuts per minute}
\text{So, in 10 minutes Henry will eat } 8 \times 10 = 80 \text{ peanuts.}

content.question: The graph shows the progress of a train travelling between cities. a) How far does the train travel in the 4 hour journey? b) Write down a rate which compares the distance travelled with the time taken. c) What was the speed of the train for this journey?

content.text: Average speed can be found using the formula:

content.label: Example 5
content.question: A cyclist travels 92 km in 4 hours. a) What was the cyclist's average speed? b) How far would the cyclist ride in 7 hours at the same rate? c) How long would it take the cyclist to ride 253 km at the same rate?
solution: \textbf{a } \text{The cyclist rode at } \frac{92 \text{ km}}{4 \text{ hours}} = 23 \text{ km per hour}
\textbf{b } \text{In 7 hours the cyclist would ride } 7 \times 23 = 161 \text{ km.}
\textbf{c } \text{The cyclist rides at 23 km per hour}
\therefore \text{ to ride 253 km it would take } \frac{253}{23} = 11 \text{ hours.}

content.text: In order to compare samples of metals or rocks, we use a rate called density. This is a measure of how compact the material is, or how much of it can be put into a given volume. The density of an object is its mass per unit of volume. For example, the density of pure gold is 19.3 grams per cm^3.
Table of common densities in g per cm^3: carbon dioxide (0.002), petrol (0.70), ice (0.92), water (1.00), milk (1.03), aluminium (2.7), iron (7.8), lead (11.3), gold (19.3), platinum (21.4)

content.label: Example 6
content.question: Find the density of a piece of timber which is 60 cm by 10 cm by 3 cm and weighs 1.62 kg.
solution: 1.62 \text{ kg} = 1.62 \times 1000 \text{ g} = 1620 \text{ g}
\text{Density} = \frac{\text{mass}}{\text{volume}}
= \frac{1620 \text{ g}}{60 \times 10 \times 3 \text{ cm}^3}
= 0.9 \text{ g per cm}^3

content.label: Example 7
content.question: How many times heavier is gold than iron?
solution: \text{The ratio of densities } \frac{\text{density of gold}}{\text{density of iron}} = \frac{19.3}{7.8} \approx 2.47
\therefore \text{ gold is 2.47 times heavier than iron.}

content.text: Roger rides his bicycle at 36 km per hour. To write his speed in m per s, consider this conversion:
Notice that travelling at 1 m per s is the same as travelling at 3.6 km per h. So, to convert: m per s into km per h we multiply by 3.6; km per h into m per s we divide by 3.6

content.label: Example 9
content.question: a) A sprinter runs at 11 m per s. Convert this to km per h. b) An aeroplane travels at 900 km per h. Convert this to m per s.
solution: \textbf{a } 11 \text{ m per s} = (11 \times 3.6) \text{ km per h} = 39.6 \text{ km per h}
\textbf{b } 900 \text{ km per h} = (900 \div 3.6) \text{ m per s} = 250 \text{ m per s}
